node.title: [Porous Flow] Unstructured Grid Heterogeneous Properties
node.bodyText:
Hello MOOSE friends,
I would like to apply heterogeneous flow properties to an unstructured grid in a PorousFlow simulation. I've read through the tutorial developed by the PorousFlow collaborators and a discussion thread from a couple of years ago and my sense is that the current tools (i.e. PiecewiseMultilinear) available in MOOSE are developed for structured grids.
My first question is whether this is still true? Is there a Function I'm overlooking that now applies properties to unstructured grids similar to PiecewiseMultilinear and PiecewiseMultiConstant?
A follow-up question. I have a mesh in .vtu format that contains the property of interest defined at cell centroids. If I import that mesh using FileMeshGenerator, is it possible to extract that to an auxiliary variable that I can use within my input file?
Thank y'all in advance for your thoughts

At least for the latter question if the mesh is the same:
You could save the mesh as Exodus .e with Paraview and use a SolutionUserobject to load the data and transfer it into an AuxVariable and link the AuxVariable to the Materials like Porosity or Permeability.
With that solution you don't need any interpolation, but the mesh should stay the same.

Yeah, if you can turn it into an exodus file then that is probably the best thing to do. You won't even need a SolutionUserObject, you can initialise elemental AuxVariables directly from the exodus file using 'initial_from_file_var = '. The example you linked does exactly that.

Thank you @1runer and @cpgr
I see where I overlooked the 'initial_from_file_var' in the linked tutorial

node.title: No call file
Deprecation messages
node.bodyText:
All,
I have received two messages for "deprecation" (please see below).  I don't understand them. Could someone provide me with examples to help me.
(1) *** Warning, This code is deprecated and will be removed in future versions:
“registerAll” in Modules is deprecated. Please update your *App.C file to call the new templated “registerAllObjects” method (e.g. ModulesApp::registerAllobject(…))
(2) For cylindrical coordinates, I use
[./Problem]
coord_type = 'RZ'
[../]
I received the message:
The parameter ‘coord_type’ is deprecated. Please use ‘Mesh/coord_type’ instead.
Please help.
S. Thomas

Hello
the messages should be saying what to do.
the first one is telling you to go in your src/base/….App.C and fix that one line
the second one is telling you to move that one line with coord_type from the problem block to the Mesh block
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
Attached is the error message on changing to ModulesApp::registerAllobject(…).
Please help.
S. Thomas

Thank you for your patience with me.
S. Thomas

node.title: Adding perturbation to a single variable after a certain number of time steps
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
Is there any way in MOOSE to add perturbation to a variable by multiplying it to a perturbation function?
For example, I want to run the simulation for 100 time steps. At time step 101, I want to multiply a variable by a perturbation function and then continue the normal simulation.
Thanks,
Ali

Hello
Is it a nonlinear variable (one you solve for) or an auxiliary variable (one you just compute with an auxkernel)
Guillaume

It is a nonlinear variable.
To be more specific, I want to multiply x velocity and z velocity by the perturbation function, just in a single time step, and in the middle of simulation.
Thanks,

So the cannon way to do that is unfortunately not great, you d have to make a new UO that changes the dof values. It wont be hard to write if you are keen on C++
However, if you want to stay on the input file scale, use a multiapp with the same mesh. Send your variable there to an auxvariable, multiply it there using a ParsedAux, then send it back using another transfer

Thank you so much.
I also have another approach in my mind. Is it possible to run for 100 time steps and then stop the simulation, then restart the simulation from time step 101, get initial condition for variables from the previous time step, and add the perturbation function in the initial condition block?
sure. There's a SumIC I think for example

node.bodyText:

variable = temp

variable = temp
black = '3'

[../]

variable = temp
[../]

variable = temp
boundary = '2'
value = 700
[../]
[]
[Materials]

block = '3'
thermal_conductivity_temperature_function = 3.048
specific_heat_temperature_function = 324.087
density_temperature_function = 11078.368
[../]
[]
[Executioner]
type = Transient
solve_type = 'PJFNK'
[]
[Outputs]
execute_on = 'timestep_end'
exodus = true
[]
then make -j8, and peacock ,but turn wrong
A 'HeatConduction' is not a registered object.
If you are trying to find this object in a dynamically linked library, make sure that
the library can be found either in your "Problem/library_path" parameter or in the
MOOSE_LIBRARY_PATH environment variable.

I would try a clean of the application libraries in order to verify that it's not an old library lingering around causing a registration issue. In your main application directory, run:
make clobberall
make -j8
Then try running your input file again.

I do ‘make clobberall’
but computer die
when do ‘make -j8' and computer die

try just “make” then
if the computer is dying it s probably running out of memory

Additionally, I would appreciate your assistance in determining if it is possible to perform calculations between the imported doping values and test functions or solution values at specific points. Your help would be greatly appreciated

node.title: Mesh refinement based on a material property
node.bodyText:
Hi,
We defined a material property for the stored energy, which is non-zero on the dislocations present in the sub-grain structure. For example, the 2D structure looks as follows in the image shown below:

In the above figure, the horizontal lines are GNBs, and the vertical lines are IDBs; in other words, they are dislocation boundaries. Since this structure is instantiated at the beginning of the simulation, I would like to refine my uniform mesh on the areas where the dislocation boundaries exist. Any suggestions?
Thanks!

is this information (where you want to refine) only stored in the material property?
if so, move it to an auxiliary variable, use that as an indicator then use initial adaptivity
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/actions/AdaptivityAction.html
Thank you! I will implement this idea of yours.

node.title: Define a flux on a boundary
node.bodyText:
I want to add a diffusion model.
$$J=-D(\frac{dx(r)}{dr}+\frac{T_Q}{T^2}x(r)\frac{dT}{dr})$$
where $T_Q$ is a const (640). T is the temperature. and x is a rate.
in the boundary the $J$ is zero.
there is my code
#pragma once
#include "IntegratedBC.h"

/**
 * $\triangledown x = \frac{T_Q}{T^2}x\triangledown T$
 * x is H/Zr rate T_Q is transfer and T is the temperature
 */

class HydrogenFluxBC : public IntegratedBC
{
public:
  static InputParameters validParams();
  HydrogenFluxBC(const InputParameters & parameters);

protected:
  virtual Real computeQpResidual() override;
private:
  const VariableValue & _temp;
  const VariableGradient & _grad_temp;
  Real _heat_transport;
};
and
#include "HydrogenFluxBC.h"

registerMooseObject("PulseApp", HydrogenFluxBC);

InputParameters
HydrogenFluxBC::validParams()
{
  InputParameters params = IntegratedBC::validParams();
  params.addRequiredCoupledVar("temperature", "coupled fuel temperature");
  return params;
}

HydrogenFluxBC::HydrogenFluxBC(const InputParameters & parameters) : IntegratedBC(parameters),
  _temp(coupledValue("temperature")),
  _grad_temp(coupledGradient("temperature"))
{
  _heat_transport = 640;
}

Real
HydrogenFluxBC::computeQpResidual()
{
  return _test[_i][_qp] * _heat_transport * _u[_qp] / std::pow(_temp[_qp], 2) * (_grad_temp[_qp] * _normals[_qp]);
}
and my test
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 1
  nx = 10
  xmin = 0
  xmax = 18e-3
  coord_type = RZ
[]

[Variables]
  [rate]
    initial_condition = 1.6
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [temp]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [temp]
    type = ParsedAux
    variable = temp
    expression = '780+170*(1-(x/18e-3)^2)'
    use_xyzt = true
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [diff]
    type = HydrogenDiffusion
    variable = rate
  []
  [transfer]
    type = HydrogenHeatTransfer
    temperature = temp
    variable = rate
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [const]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'hydrogen_diffusion Zr_density Zr_atomic_weight'
    prop_values = '1 1 1'
  []
[]

[BCs]
active = all_default
  [all]
    type = HydrogenFluxBC
    variable = rate
    temperature = temp
    boundary = 'left right'
  []
  [all_default]
    type = NeumannBC
    variable = rate
    boundary = 'left right'
    value = 0
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [FDP]
    type = FDP

    solve_type = 'PJFNK'

    petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -mat_fd_coloring_err -mat_fd_type'
    petsc_options_value = 'lu       1e-6                 ds'
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [exact]
    type = ParsedFunction
    symbol_names = 'A0'
    symbol_values = '0.7428'
    expression = 'A0 * exp(640/(780+170*(1-(x/18e-3)^2)))'
  []
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [error]
    type = NodalL2Error
    variable = rate
    function = exact
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  solve_type = 'PJFNK'
  line_search = none

  l_abs_tol = 1e-5
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-5
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  csv = true
[]

[VectorPostprocessors]
  [line]
    type = LineValueSampler
    start_point = '0 0 0'
    end_point = '18e-3 0 0'
    sort_by = x
    variable = rate
    num_points = 99
  []
[]
but the solution is wrong. anyone can help me? I think is due to the BC but i don't know how to modify it.
the Kernels is $$\triangledown J=0$$
Thanks for your help.

Hello
_u[_qp] is not x(r). It s T here since the variable is T
You should look at _q_point  instead for x
You're also missing a computeQpJacobian()
I would recommend you modify the code to avoid needing to define the Jacobian, using AD (automatic differentiation)
Guillaume
in BC the variable is x(rate). and i add computeqpjacobian the result is same.

oh yeah I see now.
ok it is "rate". Is that corresponding to x ?
The sign should be negative I think
sorry，the x is confusing. i use it for $ZrH_x$.

node.title: Wall shear stress BC in INSAD module
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I am trying to understand how one might impose a wall shear stress BC in the finite element Navier-Stokes module - or even if it makes sense to do so.
Since we have the relation wall shear stress = viscosity * du/dy where du and dy are parallel and perpendicular to the wall respectively, it made sense to try this with a Neumann BC.
I had a go at something similar to ADVectorFunctionNeumannBC, but instead of a function, passed in a vector containing wall shear components divided by viscosity.
However, the BC seemed to have no effect on the simulation, even if I changed the scale factors to be very large.
Since we might already have a no slip condition, I am having trouble understanding whether we can meaningfully impose a wall shea BC as well here - or in finite element at all.
If we were to do this, is using an integrated BC in this manner the way to go?
I should add that I am using the vector variable versions of the INSAD kernels, which I believe use the Laplace form of the INS equations.
Thanks!

So the weak term at the boundary for a given momentum component will be (for the Laplace form):
test * (n * mu * grad(u_comp) + n(comp) * pressure)

if you integrate the pressure by parts. If you don't integrate pressure by parts then you drop the second term. So if you want to supply a particular shear stress, then you can supply your vector of shear stresses and they should not be divided by the viscosity. And if you are integrating the pressure by parts, then you will also need to add a BC to handle that, e.g. a BC like:
test * n * pressure

for the vector INSAD implementation

node.title: How to add  '-std=c++17'  to compiler flags
node.bodyText:
I'd like to ask how to add  '-std=c++17'  to compiler flags. I'm asking this because after updating MOOSE, the following error comes up when compiling
/Users/sunqingpei/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/Moose.h:55:1: error: static_assert failed due to requirement '201402L >= 201703L' "MOOSE requires a C++17 compatible compiler (GCC >= 7.5.0, Clang >= 5.0.2). Please update your compiler or, if compatible, add '-std=c++17' to your compiler flags and try again. If using the MOOSE conda package, please attempt a MOOSE environment update (using mamba update --all). If this update is not successful, please create a new MOOSE environment (see https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html#uninstall-conda-moose-environment)."

You can type ‘env ‘ and look at all the environment variables defined, in particular the compiling flags.
You can then add this flags to CXXFLAGS using export CXXFLAGS="—std=c++17:$CXXFLAGS"
You should not have opened two posts for the same issue. Closing this one
